Module kivakit.core
Package com.telenav.kivakit.core.value.count

Class Bytes

java.lang.Object
com.telenav.kivakit.core.value.count.BaseCount<Bytes>
com.telenav.kivakit.core.value.count.Bytes
All Implemented Interfaces:
ByteSized, Countable, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.collection.NextIterator<Bytes>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.function.Mapper<Long,Bytes>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.Arithmetic<Bytes>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.Maximizable<Bytes>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.Minimizable<Bytes>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.Numeric<Bytes>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.Zeroable, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.string.AsString, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.string.StringFormattable, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.value.DoubleValued, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.value.FormattedLongValued, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.value.LongValued, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.value.Source<Long>, Comparable<Countable>, Supplier<Long>
public final class Bytes extends BaseCount<Bytes> implements ByteSized, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.value.DoubleValued
Represents an immutable byte count. These static factory methods allow easy construction of value objects using either long values like bytes(2034) or megabytes(3):
  • bytes(long)
  • kilobytes(long)
  • megabytes(long)
  • gigabytes(long)
  • terabytes(long)

or double precision floating point values like megabytes(3.2):

  • bytes(double)
  • kilobytes(double)
  • megabytes(double)
  • gigabytes(double)
  • terabytes(double)

The precise number of bytes in a Bytes object can be retrieved by calling bytes(). Approximate values for different units can be retrieved as double precision values using these methods:

  • kilobytes()
  • megabytes()
  • gigabytes()
  • terabytes()
Also, value objects can be constructed from strings, optionally using a Locale with valueOf(String) and valueOf(String,Locale). The string may contain a decimal or floating point number followed by optional whitespace followed by a unit (nothing for bytes, K for kilobyte, M for megabytes, G for gigabytes or T for terabytes) optionally followed by a B (for bytes). Any of these letters can be any case. So, examples of permissible string values are:
  • 37 (37 bytes)
  • 2.3K (2.3 kilobytes)
  • 2.5 kb (2.5 kilobytes)
  • 4k (4 kilobytes)
  • 35.2GB (35.2 gigabytes)
  • 1024M (1024 megabytes)

The toString() method is smart enough to convert a given value object to the most appropriate units for the given value.

Author:
Jonathan Locke
